title: Allow longer name for AWS/Azure cluster and refactoring
body: This PR 1. fixes the first part of the TODOs in #963, to unblock the user from using a long name for spot jobs on AWS. 2. moves the cluster name checking into each Cloud. 3. refactors the `cloud.supports` to `cloud.check_features_are_supported` and change the boolean return value to exception raising. 4. optimizes the failover for `InvalidClusterNameError` and `ClusterUserIdentityError` to directly move to the next cloud, as those errors apply to the whole cloud. 5. fixes minor UX issues for failover: Previously: Now: Tested (run the relevant ones): - [x] Any manual or new tests for this PR (please specify below) - [x] `sky launch -c i-am-using-a-very-long-name-for-the-aws-cluster-it-should-be-more-than-63-characters-and-hopefully-it-works-this-sentence-has-135-chars --cloud aws` - [x] AWS 244 characters: `sky launch -c i-am-using-a-very-long-name-for-the-aws-cluster-it-should-be-more-than-63-characters-and-hopefully-it-works-by-checking-the-document-of-aws-we-found-that-the-cluster-name-length-should-be-less-than-250-due-to-the-tag-limit-this-sentence-has-246-c --num-nodes 2 --cloud aws -t t3.micro` (and 245 does not work) - [x] GCP (didn't change the original tested limit) - [x] Azure 42 characters: `sky launch -c i-am-using-a-very-long-name-for-the-aws-cluste --cloud azure --region southcentralus --num-nodes 2` - [x] Lambda 64 characters: `sky launch -c i-am-using-a-very-long-name-for-the-aws-cluster-it-should-be-mor --cloud lambda` works - [x] `sky launch -c i-am-using-a-very-long-name-for-the-azure-cluster-it-should-be-more-than-63-characters-and-hopefully-it-works-this-sentence-has-136-chars --cloud azure`: correctly fails for the Azure - [x] `sky launch -c i-am-using-a-very-long-name-for-the-aws-cluster-it-should-be-more-than-63-characters-and-hopefully-it-works-this-sentence-has-135-chars --gpus A100:8`, it successfully and quickly failover through Lambda/GCP/Azure and AWS (skip the first three clouds with a single try and try all the regions on AWS).

title: [Lambda Cloud] Umbrella ticket for future TODOs
body:
### Last Updated: 4/11

### Future TODOs:

#### Multi-node support 
- [x] Done (implemented in #1718)

#### Script to update catalog
- [x] Done ( implemented in #1722)

#### Lambda in `sky gpunode`
- [ ] Done

`sky gpunode` doesn't list Lambda Cloud because Lambda Cloud does not have any K80 instances. There are two possible solutions to this problem:

- Ignore it. Currently `sky gpunode` is the same as `sky launch --gpus K80:1`, so getting Lambda listed in `sky gpunode` will make the logic (significantly) more complicated.
- Fix it.

#### `LambdaNodeProvider` tag file synchronization
- [ ] Done

We should add file locks to the tag file (good practice, even if we already have ray-related synchronization).

#### Implement `get_current_user_identity`
- [ ] Done

#### Handle `Ctrl-C` after launch
- [x] Done (fixed by #1718)

#### Update docs
- [x] Done (updated in #1659)

#### Recursive `sky launch` support
- [x] Done (fixed in #1838)

title: [Cost-Report] Filter by time frame
body: Allow for tags such as -h or -d to filter out cluster costs from last hour or last day, respectively. When used in conjunction with #1643, this can help for assessing costs for smoke tests.

title: [Cost-Report] Handle autostop clusters
body: For clusters with autostop enabled, make sure cost-report shows an n/a entry for cost.

title: [Cost-Report] Add disk price to costs as well
body: Cost will accumulate from start to down. Even when cluster is stopped but not not downed, cost is accumulated.

title: [Cost-Report] Filter by cluster name
body: Use entire name string or glob format to filter and return cost reports for relevant cluster

title: Default to ubuntu for GCP and avoid key pair checking
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Prerequisite: https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot-catalog/pull/25

Main changes:
1. Have GCP default to ubuntu image instead of Debian to fix #1604 
2. Fix the ssh connection issue caused by control master for GCP with ubuntu image
    Before the fix, the ssh connection will be disconnected when ray trying to setup the runtime dependencies, which is probably because the ssh connection is unstable when the cluster is just provisioned https://github.com/ray-project/ray/issues/16539#issuecomment-1073138982. We added retry for the ssh commands executed by `ray up`, which is ok since our setup commands are idempotent.
3. Refactor the authentication
4. Use the cloud-init to setup the key pairs for GCP, to avoid the permissions to check the key_pairs.
5. Use the cloud-init to disable the apt unattended-upgrade, to avoid the lock for `apt install` (Note: cloud-init is not installed on debian image, so we could not do it for our previous debian image)


~**This PR may cause some backward compatibility issue for GCP user who created images from our previous debian-based image, as the cloud-init is not installed on those images. Trying to fix that now.**~ It should now be fixed.


A good thing about the new image is that the `ray==2.4.0` is installed by default in the image, the provision time would be faster if #1734  is merged.

<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of GitHub CI; below are tests that launch on the cloud. -->

title: [Autostop] `sky status --refresh` after autostop fails for multi-node on GCP
body:
## Reproduction
```
# launch multinode gcp cluster
sky launch -y -d -c test --num-nodes 2 --cloud gcp tests/test_yamls/minimal.yaml

# Try sky status --refresh. This works fine.
sky status test --refresh

# Schedule autostop
sky autostop -y test -i 1

# Wait for autostop
sleep 120

# Try refreshing status - fails
sky status test --refresh
```

## Log
```
gcpuser@ray-smoke-head-ff075d77-compute:/sky_repo$ sky status test --refresh
Refreshing status for 1 cluster ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━   0% -:--:--W 01-26 08:49:45 backend_utils.py:1346] Expected 1 worker IP(s); found 0: []
W 01-26 08:49:45 backend_utils.py:1346] This could happen if there is extra output from `ray get-worker-ips`, which should be inspected below.
W 01-26 08:49:45 backend_utils.py:1346] == Output ==
W 01-26 08:49:45 backend_utils.py:1346]
W 01-26 08:49:45 backend_utils.py:1346]
W 01-26 08:49:45 backend_utils.py:1346] == Output ends ==
Clusters
NAME  LAUNCHED    RESOURCES              STATUS   AUTOSTOP  COMMAND
test  5 mins ago  2x GCP(n2-standard-8)  STOPPED  1m        sky launch -y -d -c test ...

1 cluster has auto{stop,down} scheduled. Refresh statuses with: sky status --refresh
```

## Notes
* This happens for only a short duration (~1-2 min?) while the worker is stopping (checked in cloud console). Running `sky status test --refresh` afterwards works normally and shows status as stopped.
* This happens only when using autostop. I could not replicate by manually stopping a cluster `sky stop test` and then refresh status.
* This bug is also caught by `test_smoke.py::test_autostop`
* Not fully sure if this is related to multi-node or GCP - need to check if it also happens for single node and on different clouds.

title: [UX] GCP disabled API error fix suggestion is unclear
body:
Running `sky launch` on a new GCP project (without running `sky check` first) fails because required APIs may not be enabled. This is expected.

However, at a quick glance, the error message shown to user seems to suggest going to the cloud console as a solution instead of `sky check`.

title: [GCP-VPC] sky launch can fail if user modify VPC rules
body:
Discussion from https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1594#discussion_r1084636464:

Right now SkyPilot relies on three firewall rules written in 
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/b0894c803ee010f4969d4c8ac6cf863cc820fa46/sky/skylet/providers/gcp/constants.py#L12
If user accidentally remove any of the rules of the VPC created by us, `sky launch` will fail with VPC already exist errors. 
We should make VPC creation more robust. either by using a different VPC name like `skypilot-vpc-1` or correct the firewall rules in `skypilot-vpc`.

title: [Resources] Add `cpus` in resource specification
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
Closes #387

This PR introduces the ability for users to specify resource requirements in terms of the number of vCPUs in the `Resources` class and the `resources` section in the SkyPilot yaml.

**Semantics**
1. If the instance type and accelerators are not specified, SkyPilot will use the `cpus` parameter to select an appropriate VM size from the cloud's **default** VM family (i.e., m6i for AWS, Dv5 for Azure, and n2-standard for GCP).

For example,
* `sky launch --cpus 8` or `Resources(cpus=8)`: SkyPilot will find the VMs that have exactly 8 vCPUs. Namely,
  * AWS: m6i.2xlarge
  * Azure: Standard_D8_v5
  * GCP: n2-standard-8

* `sky launch --cpus 12+` or `Resources(cpus='12+')`: SkyPilot will consider the VMs that have 12 or more vCPUs. Namely,
  * AWS: m6i.4xlarge
  * Azure: Standard_D16_v5
  * GCP: n2-standard-16

(Note: The selected three instance types have 16 vCPUs instead of 12 vCPUs, because the default instance families of the clouds do not include any VM with 12-15 vCPUs.)

2. If the accelerators are specified, the instance family can be inferred for each cloud, and SkyPilot will use the `cpus` parameter to choose the VM of the right size in the instance family. For example,
* `sky launch --gpus T4 --cpus 8+` or `Resources(accelerators='T4', cpus='8+')`: SkyPilot will choose VMs that have 1 T4 GPU along with 8 or more vCPUs. Namely,
  * AWS: g4dn.2xlarge'
  * Azure: Standard_NC8as_T4_v3
  * GCP: n1-highmem-8 (+ T4)

The same semantics applies to `cpunode`, `gpunode`, `tpunode`, and `spot launch`.

title: Python version mismatch when migrating from AWS to GCP
body:
# Description of Problem
I recently migrated my workload from AWS to GCP and ran into issues with python versions. AWS's deep learning AMI is based on LTS versions of Ubuntu with Python 3.8+, whereas the default SkyPilot GCP image uses Debian 10 with Python 3.7. This resulted in an error as some libraries in my application relied on features from Python 3.8+. 

Note that the default SkyPilot image for AWS is based on Ubuntu 22.04 and uses Python 3.9.

I believe this is a SkyPilot issue because running workloads on any cloud requires a consistent environment. This can be addressed by launching SkyPilot tasks in images that are uniform across clouds with tools such as docker or the cloud's image marketplace.

# Current workaround
I've currently made some changes to my YAML files to set up and activate conda environments for the specific Python version I need:
```yaml
setup: |
  # Create an environment with Python 3.8.
  conda create -y -n my_task python=3.8
  source activate my_task
  # Install required Python packages.

run: |
  source activate experiments
  # Run the workload script.
```

Note that this workaround only addresses Python version mismatches. Version mismatches in other libraries and programs (e.g. `gcc`) will require a different solution. 


Posted at the request of @romilbhardwaj.

title: Files not uploading to S3
body:
When using GCP for compute and S3 for storage, files generated by the task aren't automatically uploaded to S3. My SkyPilot version is 0.2.2.

Minimal example to reproduce the issue:
1. Create an AWS bucket, e.g. `skypilot-s3-bug`.
2. Launch the following task with `sky launch -c test-s3-bug s3_bug.yaml`. The contents of `s3_bug.yaml` are the following:
```yaml
resources:
  cloud: gcp

workdir: .

file_mounts:
  /data:
    name: skypilot-s3-bug
    mode: MOUNT

run: |
  echo "hello world" > /data/test.txt
```
4. After the task completes, the AWS bucket is empty.
5. Note that the file exists on the remote machine:
```
$ ssh test-s3-bug
$ cd /data/
$ ls
test.txt
$ cat test.txt 
hello world
```

A workaround is to manually sync to S3 by SSHing into the remote machine and running `aws s3 sync /data s3://skypilot-s3-bug`.

title: Syncing .git is really slow - What is the best practice?
body:
Syncing up my workdir to the cloud machine is super slow on the first time (>15min). Most of the time is spent rsyncing .git, which includes a huge amount of tiny files. But I recall this is still preferred over `git clone` my repository on the cloud VM, because this allows `sky exec` to easily sync up my changes.

What's the best practice here? Is there any downside if we skip syncing the `.git` directory? (Might also be worthwhile to prompt the user if the cwd has, say, >10000 files, and thus may take long to sync)

title: Does sky workdir sync implicitly skip "data" directory?
body: It seems `sky launch` or `sky exec` does not sync the `data` subdirectory in my workdir. Renaming it to `data1` caused it to sync. Is this expected? If so, can you prompt the user when this happens?

body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
PR Topic - integration of IBM as a new cloud provider. 
Successfully ran the following tests: 
- test_ibm_n_node_job_queue
- test_cancel_ibm
- test_ibm_autodown
- test_ibm_autostop
- test_ibm_job_queue
- test_ibm_file_mounts
- test_ibm_zone
- test_ibm_region
- test_ibm_minimal  

Notes: 
- Had to introduce new tests (that slightly differ from their original counterparts), since current tests are tailored for specific cloud providers. 
- Couldn't run tests as a batch, since some pytest config files are requiring aws credentials to run.  
- Couldn't run backwards compatibility test for reason mentioned above.  

I plan to:
 - Create a script users could run to generate a credential file located in `~/.ibm`, similarly to `aws configure`.
 - Add support for IBM's cloud object storage.  

Setup: 
Until the above mentioned script will be created, authenticate your IBM account by adding the following data in `~/.ibm/credentials.yaml` :
```
iam_api_key: <String>
resource_group_id: <String>
```
- IBM cloud API key can be created on the IBM Cloud console: Manage > Access (IAM) > Create an IBM Cloud API key. 
For the complete guide visit [this](https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/mas-cd?topic=cli-creating-your-cloud-api-key) link.
- Resource group id can be found in the IBM Cloud console: Manage > Account > Account resources > Resource groups. For the complete guide visit [this](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/account?topic=account-rgs&interface=ui) link.

title: Add GCP VPC creation if no VPC available
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Fixes https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1591

Problem: A fresh GCP project may not have any VPC created which is required for `sky launch`.
~~We add VPC creation to `sky check` if it's not found.~~

~~However, there's a design choice to make. What's the VPC name we should use, if there are many?~~
Currently, Ray just blindly uses the first VPC net in the order, which is obviously a bad idea. what if it's a user created one without sufficient permissions?
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/3cceb5cf48943782ddfb7683ccad72a8f42d0f6f/sky/skylet/providers/gcp/config.py#L509-L517

We can use `default`, but the risk is the VPC with such name may not have sufficient permissions for skypilot to work.
Now, I try to create a dedicated VPC net with a unique name `skypilot-vpc` if such VPC is not found when running `ray up`.
~~However, the consequence is that after this PR the GCP users need to re-run `sky check` to create the VPC.~~


<!-- Describe the tests ran -->

title: [UX] `sky spot queue/logs` unavailable when there are multiple spot jobs being submitted
body:
From our users:
> The `sky spot queue/logs` will remain unavailable when multiple spot jobs are being submitted.

Two possible ways to solve this:
1. Add an option (or change the meaning of `sky spot queue -r`) so that it waits until the controller is not in INIT mode.
2. Try to run the spot queue query command first when `INIT` status if found instead of directly showing the cache table.

I prefer the second option, as it is more responsive.

title: [core] Failover does not respect the blocked list
body: Great thanks to @ewzeng for finding this bug! After the fine-grained optimizer PR #930, the blocked list in the backend is no longer respected, as it will be cleared after every retry (more details https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1557#discussion_r1063198597). We should instead have the blocking all in the resources blocking set.

title: [Onprem] Job launching failed with NotImplementedError in clouds/cloud.py
body:
Hi, thanks for the great project!

I tried to deploy an on-prem sky cluster, used the current master([aa7bab7](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/commit/aa7bab7)) plus [fix_local_check](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/compare/fix_local_check), and succeeded in the cluster setup where both `ray status` and `sky status` works (no GPU shown https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1423).

However, it raises a NotImplementedError in [#L83 cloud.py](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/master/sky/clouds/cloud.py#L83) when I submit a job with `sky launch -c cluster -- ''`.

Have I chosen the wrong branch for on-prem deployment? Could you suggest a branch where we can get familiar with `sky` in a local cluster or homelab? Thank you!

title: [Spot] unnecessary retry and incorrect error type returned by spot launch
body:
`sky spot launch` may do unnecessary retry and give an incorrect error type `FAILED_NO_RESOURCE` for errors in YAML setup section.

YAML:
```
workdir: .

setup: |
  echo "Running setup!"
  pip install -r mnist/requirements.txt

run: |
  echo "Hello, SkyPilot!"
  cd mnist
  python main.py --epochs 1
```

After `spot launch` I waited for 10mins for the spot controller to retry 3 times and failed with `FAILED_NO_RESOURCE`.
```
I 01-09 21:31:38 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2421] Job submitted with Job ID: 2
I 01-09 21:42:25 spot_utils.py:327] Logs finished for job 2 (status: FAILED_NO_RESOURCE).

Shared connection to 54.80.91.45 closed.
I 01-09 21:42:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2435] Spot Job ID: 2
I 01-09 21:42:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2435] To cancel the job:               sky spot cancel 2
I 01-09 21:42:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2435] To stream job logs:              sky spot logs 2
I 01-09 21:42:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2435] To stream controller logs:       sky logs sky-spot-controller-a5c021e4 2
I 01-09 21:42:25 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2435] To view all spot jobs:           sky spot queue
```

But turns out it's an error in my `requirements.txt` (I tried to install a cuda version of pytorch on a CPU VM)

Detailed log:
```
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] Failed to setup with return code 1. Check the details in log: ~/sky_logs/sky-2023-01-09-21-31-40-877746/setup-18.118.121.104.log
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] 
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] ****** START Last lines of setup output ******
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] Running setup!
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] Defaulting to user installation because normal site-packages is not writeable
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement torch==1.12.1+cu113 (from versions: 1.7.1, 1.8.0, 1.8.1, 1.9.0, 1.9.1, 1.10.0, 1.10.1, 1.10.2, 1.11.0, 1.12.0, 1.12.1, 1.13.0, 1.13.1)
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] ERROR: No matching distribution found for torch==1.12.1+cu113
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:30 recovery_strategy.py:165] ******* END Last lines of setup output *******
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:34:47 recovery_strategy.py:250] Retrying to launch the spot cluster in 45.3 seconds.
...
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:41:53 recovery_strategy.py:165] ****** START Last lines of setup output ******
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:41:53 recovery_strategy.py:165] Running setup!
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:41:53 recovery_strategy.py:165] Defaulting to user installation because normal site-packages is not writeable
(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) I 01-09 21:41:53 recovery_strategy.py:165] ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement torch==1.12.1+cu113 (from versions: 1.7.1, 1.8.0, 1.8.1, 1.9.0, 1.9.1, 1.10.0, 1.10.1, 1.10.2, 1.11.0, 1.12.0, 1.12.1, 1.13.0, 1.13.1)

(sky-ffc9-root, pid=27672) E 01-09 21:42:09 controller.py:174] sky.exceptions.ResourcesUnavailableError: Failed to launch the spot cluster after 3 retries.
```

==========

To fix this, we may need to throw more precise error from `sky.launch` to distinguish whether it's a setup error or resource unavailable error.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/aa7bab7bc322a6fd1295c96f5c350464c2da6a52/sky/spot/recovery_strategy.py#L155

title: [Doc] Update syncing-code-artifacts.rst
[sqlite] Do not run sqlite when autostop is imported to avoid database locked
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

A user experienced the database locked problem for her spot jobs again #1509 ([detailed logs](https://gist.github.com/Michaelvll/ef9757fa4752300c6714a734c322cf85))

The problem is caused by the sqlite command is called whenever the `autostop_lib`  module is imported, even though it is not used, creating a lot of concurrent sqlite commands.

To mitigate the problem, this PR ensures the commands are only called when needed. Also, we changed to using `cursor` to run the command for setting WAL mode instead of `connection`.

  - `sky status -r`
  - `sky spot launch -n test-autostop --cloud gcp "echo hi; sleep 1800; echo bye"` and check `sky logs sky-spot-controller...` no database locked problem.
- [x] User's own workload.

title: AWS/private VPC: make no-usable-subnet errors trigger failover.
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

User trying out private VPC triggered the following error, because it hits a zone that doesn't have a private subnet, and the node provider threw `cli_logger.abort()` that crashed the whole program rather than triggering failover.

```
I 01-04 21:07:45 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1377] Launching on AWS us-east-1 (us-east-1c)
I 01-04 21:07:50 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:733] ====== stdout ======
2023-01-04 21:07:46,516	INFO commands.py:270 -- Cluster: generate-embeddings
2023-01-04 21:07:47,009	INFO commands.py:349 -- Checking External environment settings
2023-01-04 21:07:47,009	VINFO utils.py:150 -- Creating AWS resource `ec2` in `us-east-1`
2023-01-04 21:07:49,416	VINFO utils.py:150 -- Creating AWS resource `iam` in `us-east-1`
2023-01-04 21:07:49,818	VINFO utils.py:150 -- Creating AWS resource `ec2` in `us-east-1`

I 01-04 21:07:50 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:736] ====== stderr ======
Dropping the empty legacy field head_node. head_nodeis not supported for ray>=2.0.0. It is recommended to removehead_node from the cluster config.
Dropping the empty legacy field worker_nodes. worker_nodesis not supported for ray>=2.0.0. It is recommended to removeworker_nodes from the cluster config.
2023-01-04 21:07:50,644	PANIC config.py:626 -- No usable subnets matching availability zone ['us-east-1c'] found for node type ray.head.default.
Choose a different availability zone or try manually creating an instance in your specified region to populate the list of subnets and trying this again.
```
Moreover, user cannot `sky down` as it triggers the same error due to this being thrown in the bootstrapping stage of the node provider.

This PR changes all such abort() into triggering failover.

    - [x] `sky launch -c dbg --region us-east-1 -i2 --cloud aws  -t t3.xlarge` succeeded, skipping the problematic zone

title: [State] Disable WAL when running on WSL
body:
We enabled write ahead logging for state.db in #1513, but it breaks compatibility for WSL (`sqlite3.OperationalError: locking protocol`; see [wsl issue](https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/2395#issuecomment-339913847)), particularly when running tests.

This PR puts a check for WSL before enabling WAL on `state.db`.

Note that this "fix" is a band-aid. We _may_ still see issues when WSL users try to access state.db concurrently from multiple processes.

This PR does not touch WAL for `skylet_config.db`.  

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] A small smoke test (`bash tests/run_smoke_tests.sh using_file_mounts`) on WSL to ensure fix works
- [x] Snippet from #1509 on ubuntu machine
- [x] Can someone help test mac (by running snippet from #1509)?

title: [AWS] Support per-region ssh proxy command
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Per user request, this PR supports per-region ssh proxy command.

Here is the new `~/.sky/config.yaml`:
```
aws:
  # The VPC to use in each region.
  #
  # If this is set, any region without a unique VPC with this name will not be
  # able to launch SkyPilot nodes. SkyPilot's failover will still properly
  # function to look for such an eligible region.
  #
  # Optional; default: None (SkyPilot will use the default VPC in each region).
  vpc_name: skypilot-vpc

  # Set to true to use private IPs to communicate between the local client and
  # any SkyPilot nodes. This requires the networking stack is properly set up;
  # in particular, this flag requires the existence of subnets with name tags
  # containing the substring "private", which will be used to hold SkyPilot
  # nodes.
  #
  # This flag is typically set together with 'vpc_name' above and
  # 'auth.ssh_proxy_command'.
  #
  # Optional; default: False.
  use_internal_ips: True

  # If set, this is passed as the '-o ProxyCommand' option for any SSH
  # connections (including rsync) used to communicate between the local client
  # and any SkyPilot nodes. This option is not used between SkyPilot nodes,
  # since they may not have such a proxy set up.
  #
  # Useful for using a jump server to communicate with SkyPilot nodes hosted in
  # private subnets without public IPs.
  #
  # Optional; default: None.
  # use the same proxy command for all the regions
  # ssh_proxy_command: ssh -W %h:%p -i ~/.ssh/sky-key -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no ec2-user@ip1
  #
  # Or, it is possible to specify per-region proxy command
  ssh_proxy_command:
      us-east-1: ssh -W %h:%p -i ~/.ssh/key1 -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no ec2-user@ip1
      us-east-2: ssh -W %h:%p -i ~/.ssh/key2 -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no ec2-user@ip2
```

TODO:
- [x] distinguish the cloud providers for the per-region proxy command.

title: Add support for Lambda Labs
body:
This PR adds support for Lambda Labs GPU Cloud.

### How to try out [updated 1/27/2023]:

#### Setup

1. Go to [https://cloud.lambdalabs.com/api-keys](https://cloud.lambdalabs.com/api-keys) to generate an API key and add the line `api_key = [YOUR_API_KEY]` to `~/.lambda_cloud/lambda_keys`.
2.  Run `sky check`.

#### Launch

Some things you can run:

- `sky gpunode --instance-type gpu_1x_a100_sxm4`
- `sky launch --cloud lambda examples/minimal.yaml --down`
- `sky launch --cloud lambda --gpus A100 examples/huggingface_glue_imdb_app.yaml`

### Features and Limitations

Some limitations are:

- Only 1-node clusters are supported (multi-node support coming soon!)
- Spot instances are not supported (Lambda Cloud does not provide this feature).
- Stopping and autostopping are not supported (Lambda Cloud does not provide this feature).
- `--image-id` is not supported (Lambda Cloud does not provide this feature)
- Lambda Labs rate limits its API (~1 launch every 10 seconds), so launching multiple clusters at once may fail.

Everything else should work. If you find a feature that is not supported, please let me know!

### Acknowledgements

A large part of this PR is based on @gmittal's earlier work (#1136).

All suggestions and feedback are welcome! @concretevitamin @Michaelvll @infwinston @romilbhardwaj @gmittal

title: Minor logging fix.
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Before
```
» sky exec dbg2 echo hi                                                                                                                                                          1 ↵
Task from command: echo hi
Executing task on cluster dbg2...
sky.exceptions.ClusterNotUpError: Executing tasks on: skipped for cluster 'dbg2' (status: INIT). It is only allowed for UP clusters.
```

After
```
» sky exec dbg2 echo hi
Task from command: echo hi
Executing task on cluster dbg2...
sky.exceptions.ClusterNotUpError: Executing tasks: skipped for cluster 'dbg2' (status: STOPPED). It is only allowed for UP clusters.
```

title: [TPU VM] Avoid infinite recursion when cleaning up spot TPU VM
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Describe the changes in this PR:

Our user observe that terminating an TPU VM can cause a infinite recursion (checked with py-spy) for status refreshing and tearing down the cluster. The reason could be the following:
1. The spot TPU VM is in the local cluster cache table, but already terminated in the console.
2. When the user try to terminate the cluster with `sky down cluster-name`, SkyPilot tries to refresh the cluster status using gcloud and try to clean up the TPU VM as we cannot find the cluster in the console. https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/1ad086874dc51751232ea7fa540c975709d915a5/sky/backends/backend_utils.py#L1610-L1613
3. In the `teardown_no_lock`, we will call the refresh again causing the infinite recursion. https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/1ad086874dc51751232ea7fa540c975709d915a5/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L2668-L2669

The bug is introduced since we enforce the cluster refresh for the spot instances when the `refresh_cluster_status_handle ` is called in #1513

<!-- Describe tests ran in a "Tested:" section -->
<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of Github CI; the below are additional tests. -->

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] `sky launch -c tpu-vm --use-spot test-tpuvm.yaml`; delete the tpu vm from the console; `sky status -r` (with the current master branch 1ad0868, it will loop infinitely)
  ```
  # test-tpuvm.yaml
  resources:
    accelerators: tpu-v3
    accelerator_args:
      tpu_vm: true
    use_spot: true
  ```

Low priority as updating with setup is my workaround.

title: UX: if unmanaged spot is used, print a hint that only managed spot automatically recovers
body:
If we detected unmanaged spot is used, we should print a hint a la
- Unmanaged spot cluster is being created, which does not automatically recover from preemptions. 
- To have auto recovery, use managed spot jobs instead: CLI `sky spot launch`, Python `sky.spot_launch()`.

title: [autostop] setstate instead of set_state
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

It looks like `__set_state__` is being used for setting `down=False` during deserialization. However, this is a typo so it never works (https://docs.python.org/3/library/pickle.html#object.__setstate__). Also it does not look like `state.setdefault` will work as `self.down` is always set.

@Michaelvll could you confirm its the original intention is for deserialization? Otherwise, we should remove it as it is not been used in other places.
